message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cardiobacterium hominis is a gram-negative bacillus, and cephalosporins such as ceftriaxone are effective against it. Ampicillin is not typically effective against gram-negative bacteria. Cefazolin may be effective against some gram-negative bacteria, but ceftriaxone is a better choice in this case. Rifampin is not typically used as monotherapy for bloodstream infections.

We refer to UpToDate for help. Cardiobacterium hominis is a fastidious gram-negative bacillus and is sensitive to ceftriaxone. Therefore, switching to intravenous ceftriaxone is the most appropriate next step in management. Ampicillin is not effective against gram-negative bacteria, and cefazolin and rifampin are not the recommended treatment options for this organism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cardiobacterium hominis is susceptible to beta-lactam antibiotics such as penicillins and cephalosporins, so switching to intravenous ceftriaxone is the most appropriate next step in management. Vancomycin is not effective against gram-negative bacteria like C. hominis. Adding intravenous rifampin is unnecessary since ceftriaxone is sufficient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cardiobacterium hominis is a gram-negative bacillus, so options A and C are not appropriate. Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin that is effective against C. hominis and is commonly used in infective endocarditis treatment. Rifampin is usually not used as monotherapy for endocarditis. Therefore, the most appropriate next step is to switch to intravenous ceftriaxone.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cardiobacterium hominis is sensitive to third-generation cephalosporins, so switching to intravenous ceftriaxone would be the most appropriate next step in management. Ampicillin is not effective against gram-negative bacteria, and cefazolin is not effective against Cardiobacterium. Adding rifampin may be beneficial, but it is not the most appropriate initial step.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cardiobacterium hominis is susceptible to third-generation cephalosporins like ceftriaxone. Ampicillin may still be effective but ceftriaxone is the better option. Cefazolin is not effective against gram-negative bacteria. Rifampin may be considered as an adjunct therapy, but switching to a more appropriate antibiotic is the first step.

We refer to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention website for help. Cardiobacterium hominis is susceptible to ceftriaxone, so switching to this antibiotic is the most appropriate next step. Ampicillin is not effective against this organism, and cefazolin is not a recommended treatment for infective endocarditis caused by gram-negative bacteria. Adding rifampin is not necessary in this case.

We refer to the Merck Manual for help. Cardiobacterium hominis is susceptible to penicillin and cephalosporins. Therefore, switching to intravenous ceftriaxone, a third-generation cephalosporin, is the most appropriate next step in management. Intravenous ampicillin is also an option, but it may not have as broad-spectrum coverage as ceftriaxone. Intravenous cefazolin is not effective against gram-negative bacilli like Cardiobacterium hominis. Adding intravenous rifampin is not necessary at this time.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cardiobacterium hominis is a gram-negative bacilli that is sensitive to third-generation cephalosporins such as ceftriaxone. Ampicillin and cefazolin are not effective against gram-negative organisms, and rifampin is not typically used as monotherapy for infective endocarditis. Therefore, switching to intravenous ceftriaxone is the most appropriate next step in management.

We refer to UpToDate for help. Cardiobacterium hominis is a fastidious, gram-negative bacillus that is part of the normal oral flora but can cause infective endocarditis. The agent is susceptible to penicillins, cephalosporins, and aminoglycosides. Intravenous ceftriaxone is a commonly used agent to treat infective endocarditis caused by Cardiobacterium hominis. Ampicillin is also an option, but some strains of Cardiobacterium hominis have shown resistance to ampicillin. Cefazolin is not typically used to treat infective endocarditis and rifampin is not necessary in this case.
